headline.main: NEW -YORK CITY.; The Cholera. FRANKLIN-STREET HOSPITAL,. Funeral of the Mexican Volunteer, Martin Feeney. The Greytown Outrage--Weeting at the Irving House. Kansas-Nebraska Emigration New - York State Teachers' Association. THE PEARL-STREET FIRE?? TEMPERANCE TRACTS?? PAINFUL ACCIDENT IN THE NINTH WARD. ARRESTED FOR PASSING ALTERED MONEY
A French War Steamer In Quarantine at Norfolk, &c..

docs.lead_paragraph: The Board of Health of this city, have ordered the French war steamer Chimera, lately arrived here from Havana, into quarantine, on suspicion of her having yellow fever on board. The Governor of Virginia arrived here yesterday from Old Point Comfort, and visited the Navy-Yard, where he was received with a salute.

headline.main: City Schools--The Proposed Testimonial to Mr. McKeen.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Teachers of the Ward Schools have, for some time past had it in contemplation to present a service of plate to JOSEPH McKEEN, Esq., as a token of esteem for his course while City Superintendent. Some embarrassment, however, has been occasioned since Mr. McKEEN's acceptance of the office of Assistant-Superintendent, in consequence of a rule of the Board of Education which forbids such manifestations towards persons in office.

docs.lead_paragraph: A SAD SIGHT.--There are many of them now-a-days, no doubt, but not always as public as the one which has just. affected us-to tears. A German immigrant. with no mental development in proportion to his physical frame, sitting on the side walk, weeping over a dying child in his arms, with two others standing near him, and all in the hot burning sun.

docs.lead_paragraph: If a ghost ever appears to us, we hope it will be that of THOMAS W. SWEETZER, or we want good spirits, if any, to confront our startled visions. We don't know Mr. SWEETZER'S habits or creed. He may have taken a poor newspaper, been fond of Scotch snuff, and even approved of Abolitionism, for anything that at present recurs to us.

headline.main: LONG-ISLAND.; First Congregational Methodist Church, Brooklyn.

docs.lead_paragraph: A lecture way delivered in this Church, on the corner of Tillary and Lawrence-streets, Brooklyn, Tuesday evening, by Rev. Mr. WELSH, formerly a Roman Catholic Priest, and as he expressed himself, one of the most bigotted. The audience in attendance was not large, but very orderly.

docs.lead_paragraph: A correspondence at Rome writes as follows: One of the many robberies committed last Winter on the road from Civita Vecchia to this city was on the carriage of two English ladies, named IRELAND. The position who drove the horses from the station to Castel-Guidi pretended to arrange the harness, when the brigands appeared, and completely pillaged the carriage.

headline.main: IOWA.; Appearance and Characteristics of the Country.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ill health drove me, a few months since, from your city, since which I have traveled over a very large portion of Iowa-indeed, nearly all of what is called Southern Iowa, comprising that part of the State included between the Mississippi and Missouri rivers on the East and West, the Missouri State line on the South, and the north line of the third tier of counties on the North.

headline.main: NEW-YORK CITY.; The Cholera. The Affray between the Turners and the Irish--Discharge of the Turners. The Attack Upon the Turners--Further Particulars. DESTRUCTIVE FIRE. FOOT-RACE AT FRANCONI'S HIPPODROME. LAUNCH AT HOBOKEN. PANEL ROBBERY. CORRECTION. JERSEY CITY AND HOBOKEN DIRECTORY. PROSPECT OF A REMOVAL OF THE OFFAL. The Board of Education. INQUEST NEAR RONDOUT. COMMON PLEAS--SPECIAL TERM. BOLD HOUSE ROBBERY.
FROM EL PASO.; The Mail Attacked by Indians--Army Movements--Forgeries, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: MESSRS. EDITORS: The Santa Fe and El Paso mail, in charge of Capt. B. DAILEY, a rivod here on last Monday morning, having performed the trip through in twenty-five days, and traveling very little at night. The Indians made an attack on the mail going up at Eagle Spring.
